overview: Register land and property in England and Wales with Land Registry, register in Scotland or Northern Ireland, transferring ownership
title: Registering land or property with Land Registry

table.body:
By law, you must register all land or property in your name with Land Registry if:

+ you've bought it
+ it's been given to you
+ you've [taken over the ownership](/registering-land-or-property-with-land-registry/transfer-ownership-of-your-property "transfer ownership of your property") from someone else (eg you've inherited a property) 

^Most people use a solicitor or conveyancer to register, but you can do it yourself.^ 

You may also need to register land that you lease, especially if there are 7 or more years left on the lease. [Find out more](http://www.landregistry.gov.uk/professional/guides/practice-guide-25 "Leases - when to register"){:rel="external"} or [contact Land Registry](http://www.landregistry.gov.uk/public/contacts "Contact Land Registry"){:rel="external"} if you aren’t sure.
table.title: When you must register

table.body:
Most people use a solicitor or conveyancer to do this when they buy or inherit a property, but you can do this yourself.

s1. Carry out a search from the Land Charges Department. You can do this using [form K15 'Application for an original search' (PDF, 185KB)](http://www.landregistry.gov.uk/_media/downloads/forms/k15.pdf "Form K15: Application for an official search (PDF, 185KB)"){:rel="external"} to search against all previous owners since 1925.
s2. Complete [form FR1 'Application for first registration' (PDF, 82KB).](http://www.landregistry.gov.uk/_media/downloads/forms/FR1.pdf "Form FR1: Application for first registration (PDF, 82KB)"){:rel="external"} 
s3. Fill in [form TR1 'Transfer of whole of registered title(s)' PDF, 85KB.](http://www.landregistry.gov.uk/_media/downloads/forms/TR1.pdf "form TR1 'Transfer of whole of registered title(s)' PDF, 85KB"){:rel="external"}
s4. Enclose a plan showing where the land is (if not already on the deeds), the original deeds and documents of title and the Land Charges search results.
s5. You may need to enclose extra forms if you're not a legal conveyancer, if your property is leasehold, if there are overriding interests in your property or if you've paid [Stamp Duty](/buy-sell-your-home/stamp-duty "Stamp Duty") (see 'Extra documents you may need' below). 
s6. Fill out 2 copies of the [DL form 'List of documents' (PDF, 125KB).](http://www.landregistry.gov.uk/_media/downloads/forms/DL.pdf "Form DL 'List of documents' (PDF, 125KB)"){:rel="external"}
s7. Enclose the [registration fee](http://www.landregistry.gov.uk/professional/fees/fees-calculator "Online fee calculator"){:rel="external"} - this depends on the value of your property and whether you're registering it voluntarily or not. 
s8. Send your forms to the [appropriate Land Registry office](http://www.landregistry.gov.uk/public/contacts/offices/office-finder "Land Registry office finder"){:rel="external"}


%If any of the original deeds are missing, [contact Land Registry](http://www.landregistry.gov.uk/public/contacts "Contact Land Registry"){:rel="external"} for advice.%

##Extra documents you may need

Depending on your circumstances, you may also need to send:

- [form ID1 'Certificate of identity' (PDF, 62KB)](http://www.landregistry.gov.uk/_media/downloads/forms/ID1.pdf "Form ID1: Certificate of identity for a private individual (PDF, 62KB)"){:rel="external"} - you need to provide this as proof of identity if you aren't a legal conveyancer
- [form DI 'Disclosable overriding interests' (PDF, 92KB)](http://www.landregistry.gov.uk/_media/downloads/forms/DI.pdf "Form DI: Disclosable overriding interests (PDF, 92KB)"){:rel="external"} if there are unregistered interests in the property that aren't mentioned in the deeds (eg a short-term lease or a right of occupation) - [find out more](http://www.landregistry.gov.uk/professional/guides/practice-guide-15 "Overriding interests and their disclosure"){:rel="external"} from the Land Registry
- a Land Transaction Return certificate from HMRC if you've paid [Stamp Duty](/buy-sell-your-home/stamp-duty "Stamp Duty") 
- the original and a copy of the lease, if you're applying to register leasehold land or property


*[HMRC]: Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs
table.title: Register for the first time

table.body:
Even if you don't have to register (eg because you bought the property before 1990 when registration became compulsory), you may find it useful to register your property voluntarily, because it:

+ shows proof of ownership
+ helps to [protect your land from fraud](protect-a-property-against-fraud "Protect a property against fraud")
+ makes it easier to change ownership

You could get a discount of 25% on the registration fee if you're [registering land or property voluntarily for the first time.](/registering-land-or-property-with-land-registry/register-for-the-first-time "Register for the first time")

^[Find out if your property is already registered](http://www.landregistry.gov.uk/public/faqs/how-do-i-find-out-if-a-property-or-piece-of-land-is-registered "Find out if a property is registered: Land Registry"){:rel="external"} on the Land Registry website.^
table.title: Voluntary registration
Transfer ownership of your property

table.body:
You're likely to be at risk if:

- your property’s mortgage has been paid off
- your property is empty or you're letting it
- you're abroad, absent, ill or in a care home

There are several things you can do to protect your property from fraud.

##Register your property

Not all properties are registered, as registration hasn't always been compulsory. [Registering](register-for-the-first-time "Register for the first time") your property:

+ provides an official record of who currently owns the land
+ means you might be able to get compensation from Land Registry if you suffer a financial loss because of fraud

##Keep your details up to date

It's free to update your contact details. You can register up to 3 addresses (including email) and keep them updated using the form below. 

$D [Download 'Updating registered owners’ contact address' (PDF, 39KB) from the Land Registry.](http://www.landregistry.gov.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0018/2574/updating_contact_form.pdf "Download 'Updating registered owners’ contact address' form"){:rel="external"} $D

You can also ask your legal adviser if they’ll act as a 'care of’ address. This means any letters Land Registry sends to you will also be sent to them.

##Put a restriction on your title

A restriction limits the powers of the registered owner to deal with or dispose of a property (eg sell it or use it to raise a mortgage). This could help stop someone forging your signature on a deed to try to defraud you.

$E
**Example:**

If you have an ‘LL’ restriction on your title, somebody can only register the sale or mortgage of the property if a professional conveyancer certifies that they're the owner.
$E

Speak to a legal adviser about putting a restriction on the title.

##What to do about property fraud

^If you're worried you may be the victim of property fraud, [contact Land Registry](http://www.landregistry.gov.uk/public/contacts/offices/office-finder "Find your nearest Land Registry office"){:rel="external"} immediately. You should also get [legal advice](http://legaladviserfinder.justice.gov.uk/AdviserSearch.do "Contact a legal adviser"){:rel="external"} and [contact the police.](http://www.police.uk/ "Contact the police"){:rel="external"}^
table.title: Protect a property against fraud

table.body:
The Land Registry only deals with land and property in England and Wales.

##Scotland

Register your land or property with [Register of Scotland.](http://www.ros.gov.uk/public/services/index.html "Register of Scotland"){:rel="external"}

##Northern Ireland

[Land & Property Services](http://www.dfpni.gov.uk/lps "Land and Property Services"){:rel="external"} handles registration and other property services in Northern Ireland.
